page.title: List of geographic acronyms and initialisms

revision.text:
This is a '''list of geographic acronyms and initialisms'''. [[Acronyms]] are abbreviations formed by the initial letter or letters of the words that make up a multi-word term. Other names have been formed from the initials of multiple people, geographic names, or ordinary words. The main difference between the two is that, in the latter group, the names can be ordered in whatever way is convenient to form the new name.
For the most part, the geographic names in this list were derived from three or more other names or words. Those derived from only two names are usually considered [[portmanteaus]] and can be found in the [[List of geographic portmanteaus]]. However, there are exceptions to this two/three rule in both lists, so it is more of a guideline than a hard-and-fast rule. {{TOC right}}
==Acronyms==
===Company names===
Many of these places are former [[company towns]].
* [[Abanda, Alabama]] — '''A'''tlanta, '''B'''irmingham '''AND''' '''A'''tlantic Railroad<ref name=pnAla /> * [[Alco, Louisiana]] — '''A'''lexandria '''L'''umber '''CO'''mpany<ref name=LApn /> * [[Alcoa, Tennessee]] — '''AL'''uminum '''CO'''mpany of '''A'''merica * [[Alpoca, West Virginia]] — '''AL'''pha '''POCA'''hontas Coal Company<ref name=WVpn />{{rp|43}} * [[Ameagle, West Virginia]] — '''AM'''erican '''EAGLE''' Colliery<ref name=WVpn />{{rp|79}} * [[Asco, West Virginia]] — '''A'''tlantic '''S'''mokeless '''CO'''al Company<ref name="WVpn" >{{cite book|last=Kenny|first=Hamill|title=West Virginia Place Names: Their Origin and Meaning, Including the Nomenclature of the Streams and Mountains|url=https://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.b3624093|year=1945|publisher=The Place Name Press|location=Piedmont, WV}}</ref>{{rp|86}} * [[Atco, Georgia]] — '''A'''merican '''T'''extile '''CO'''mpany<ref name=GApn /> * [[Atco, New Jersey]] — '''A'''tlantic '''T'''ransport '''CO'''mpany<ref name=Stewart /> * [[Ballico, California]] — '''BALLI'''ntine '''CO'''mpany * [[Becco, West Virginia]] — '''B'''ufalo '''E'''agle '''C'''olliery '''CO'''mpany<ref name=WVpn />{{rp|43}} * [[Cadomin]], Alberta — '''CA'''nadian '''DO'''minion '''MIN'''e<ref name=cpna /> * Calavo Gardens, California<ref>{{cite gnis|1656448|Calavo Gardens, California}}</ref> — '''CAL'''ifornia '''AVO'''cado Growers Association<ref name="CApn">{{cite book|last1=Gudde|first1=Erwin Gustav|title=California Place Names: The Origin and Etymology of Current Geographical Names|date=2010|publisher=University of California Press|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ibMwDwAAQBAJ}}</ref> * [[Caldor, California]] — '''CAL'''ifornia '''DO'''o'''R''' Company<ref name=CApn /> * [[Calgro, California]] — '''CAL'''ifornia '''GRO'''wers Wineries<ref name=CApn /> * [[Calpack, California]] — '''CAL'''ifornia '''PACK'''ing Corporation<ref name=CApn /> * [[Calpet, Wyoming]] — '''CAL'''ifornia '''PET'''roleum Company<ref name=Stewart /> * [[Calwa, California]] — '''CAL'''ifornia '''W'''ine '''A'''ssociation<ref name=CApn /> * [[Canora, Saskatchewan]] — '''CA'''nadian '''NO'''rthern '''RA'''ilway<ref name=gnSK /> * [[Ceepeecee, British Columbia]] — either '''C'''anadian '''P'''acking '''C'''orporation or '''C'''alifornia '''P'''acking '''C'''orporation, or likely first Canadian, then California<ref name=bcpn /> * [[Charmco, West Virginia]] — '''CHAR'''leston '''M'''illing '''CO'''mpany<ref name=WVpn />{{rp|165}} * [[Cimic, Illinois]] — '''C'''hicago '''I'''llinois '''M'''idland Railroad, '''I'''llinois '''C'''entral Railroad<ref name="pnIll">{{cite book|last1=Callary|first1=Edward|title=Place Names of Illinois|date=October 2009|publisher=University of Illinois Press|location=Champaign, Illinois|isbn=978-0-252-03356-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZvHgwa-XImcC}}</ref> * Cipsco Park, Illinois — '''C'''entral '''I'''llinois '''P'''ublic '''S'''ervice '''CO'''mpany<ref name=pnIll /> * [[Clinchco, Virginia]] — for both '''CLINCH'''field Railroad and '''CLINCH'''field Coal '''CO'''rporation<ref name=VApn /> * [[Closplint, Kentucky]] — '''CLO'''ver '''SPLINT''' Coal Company<ref name=KYpn /> * [[Cofoco, West Virginia]] — '''CO'''al '''FO'''rk '''CO'''al Company, now known as [[Coal, West Virginia]]<ref name=WVpn />{{rp|43}} * [[Colwich, Kansas]] — '''COL'''orado ===Personal names=== These are derived from the names of a single person and always include parts, but not all, of more than one of their names. Since the order of such names is fixed, they can be considered a form of acronym. When combining names of more than one person, the order is not fixed, so such names are either in the [[List of geographic portmanteaus]] if from only two names, or in the Initialism section below for those from multiple names. * [[Aflex, Kentucky]] — '''A'''. ==Initialisms== The names in this section are composed of elements of three or more other names or words. Unlike acronyms, there's no predefined ordering for the names, so they can be placed in whatever order makes for a good name. Names combining only two other names are more properly called ''[[portmanteaus]]''. See [[List of geographic portmanteaus]] for such names.

{{see also|List of museums}} {{refimprove|date=January 2017}} A '''national museum''' is a [[museum]] maintained by a [[state (polity)|state]]. In many countries it denotes a museum run by the [[central government]], and often is restricted to a few museums, mostly in the capital, while other museums are run by regional or local government, or foundations. In other countries a much larger number of museums are run by the central government, some quite small. Some national museums use the term in their name, but others do not; some museums just adopt the term as a matter of branding.
The following is an incomplete and not very reliable list of national museums: {{Expand list|date=August 2008}} {{TOC right}}

page.title: Rape during the Bangladesh Liberation War

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/43.229.165.68|43.229.165.68]] ([[User talk:43.229.165.68|talk]]) to last version by GeneralizationsAreBad

revision.text:
The '''regional indicator symbols''' are a set of 26 alphabetic [[Unicode]] characters (A–Z) intended to be used to encode [[ISO 3166-1 alpha-2]] two-letter [[country code]]s in a way that allows optional special treatment.
These were defined as part of the Unicode 6.0 support for [[emoji]], as an alternative to encoding separate characters for each country flag. Although they can be displayed as Roman letters, it is intended that implementations may choose to display them in other ways, such as by using [[national flag]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://babelstone.blogspot.com/2009/11/whats-new-in-unicode-60.html|title=What's new in Unicode 6.0|author=[[Andrew West (linguist)|Andrew West]]|publisher=Babelstone|accessdate=2014-08-18}}</ref><ref name=n3727>{{cite web|url=https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2009/09379-n3727-regionalindicators.pdf|title=N3727: Proposal to encode Regional Indicator Symbols in the UCS|author=[[Michael Everson]] and Ken Whistler|publisher=Working Group Document, ISO/IEC JTC1/SC2/WG2 and UTC|accessdate=2014-08-18}}</ref> The Unicode FAQ indicates that this mechanism should be used and that symbols for national flags will not be directly encoded.<ref>{{cite web | title = Unicode FAQ: Emoji and Dingbats | publisher = The Unicode Consortium | url = https://www.unicode.org/faq/emoji_dingbats.html | date = 2009-10-28 | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref>
They are encoded in the range {{unichar|1F1E6|regional indicator symbol letter a|html=}} to {{unichar|1F1FF|regional indicator symbol letter z|html=}} within the [[Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement]] block in the [[Supplementary Multilingual Plane]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://unicode.org/charts/PDF/Unicode-6.0/U60-1F100.pdf|title=Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement, Range 1F100 - 1F1FF, The Unicode Standard, Version 6.0|publisher=Unicode Consortium|date=2010|accessdate=2014-08-18}}</ref>
==Emoji flag sequences== <!-- This section should become its own page (like "Emoji flags") when/if the proposal to add subdivisions is accepted (https://www.unicode.org/reports/tr51/tr51-10.html#flag-emoji-tag-sequences) --> A pair of regional indicator symbols is referred to as an ''emoji flag sequence'' (although it represents a specific region, not a specific flag for that region).<ref name="UTR51Flags">{{cite web|url=https://unicode.org/reports/tr51/#Flags| date=2018-05-21 |title=UTR #51: Unicode Emoji, Annex B: Valid Emoji Flag Sequences|publisher=Unicode Consortium}}</ref>
Out of the 676 possible pairs of regional indicator symbols (26 × 26), only 270 are considered valid Unicode region codes. These are a subset of the region sequences in the [[Common Locale Data Repository]] (CLDR):<ref name="UTR51Flags"/><ref>{{cite web|url=https://unicode.org/reports/tr35/#Validity_Data|title=UTR #35: Unicode Locale Data Markup Language (LDML), Validity Data |publisher=Unicode Consortium}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://unicode.org/cldr/latest/common/validity/region.xml | title=CLDR v34 Region Validity Data | date=2018-10-15 |work=Unicode Common Locale Data Repository (CLDR)}}</ref> * All 256 regular region sequences in the CLDR * Two of the 35 macroregion sequences in the CLDR (EU and UN) * All 12 [[Deprecation|deprecated]] region sequences in the CLDR (strongly discouraged—intended for backward compatibility only) {| class="wikitable sortable Unicode" |+ {{nowrap|List of current emoji flag sequences}} |- ! class="unsortable" | flag ! code ! region<ref name="EmojiSeq">{{cite web|url=https://unicode.org/Public/emoji/latest/emoji-sequences.txt| date=2018-05-22 |title=UCD: Emoji Sequence Data for UTR #51|publisher=Unicode Consortium}}</ref> <!-- subdivision column will go here when/if Unicode proposal is accepted --> |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇨]]}} || AC || [[Ascension Island]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇩]]}} || AD || [[Andorra]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇪]]}} || AE || [[United Arab Emirates]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇫]]}} || AF || [[Afghanistan]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇬]]}} || AG || [[Antigua and Barbuda|Antigua & Barbuda]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇮]]}} || AI || [[Anguilla]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇱]]}} || AL || [[Albania]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇲]]}} || AM || [[Armenia]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇴]]}} || AO || [[Angola]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇶]]}} || AQ || [[Antarctica]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇷]]}} || AR || [[Argentina]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇸]]}} || AS || [[American Samoa]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇹]]}} || AT || [[Austria]] |- | {{huge|[[🇦🇺]]}} || AU || A separate mechanism (emoji tag sequences) is used for regional flags, such as Scotland or California<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://unicode.org/reports/tr51/| date=2017-05-18 |title=UTR #51: Unicode Emoji|publisher=Unicode Consortium}}</ref> It uses {{unichar|1F3F4|WAVING BLACK FLAG}} and formatting [[Tags (Unicode block)|tag characters]] instead of regional indicator symbols.
== Unicode block == {{Main|Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement|l1=Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement (Unicode block)}} {{Unicode chart Enclosed Alphanumeric Supplement|subset=regional}}
== Background == In 2007 a draft proposal was presented to the Unicode Technical Committee to encode [[emoji]] symbols, specifically those in widespread use on mobile phones by Japanese telecommunications companies [[NTT DoCoMo|DoCoMo]], [[KDDI]], and [[SoftBank]].<ref>{{cite web | first = Kat | last = Momoi | first2 = Mark | last2 = Davis | first3 = Markus | last3 = Scherer | authorlink = | title = L2/07-257: Working Draft Proposal for Encoding Emoji Symbols | date = 2007-08-03 | url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2007/07257-emoji-wd.html | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref> The proposed symbols included ten national flags:<ref>{{cite web | title = Unicode Mapping for Emoji with Reference to Japanese Carriers, AU/KDDI, DoCoMo, and Softbank | url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2007/07257-emoji-wd-table.zip | format=ZIP archive file format | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref> [[Flag of China|China]] (🇨🇳), [[Flag of Germany|Germany]] (🇩🇪), [[Flag of Spain|Spain]] (🇪🇸), [[Flag of France|France]] (🇫🇷), the [[Flag of the United Kingdom|UK]] (🇬🇧), [[Flag of Italy|Italy]] (🇮🇹), [[Flag of Japan|Japan]] (🇯🇵), [[Flag of South Korea|South Korea]] (🇰🇷), [[Flag of Russia|Russia]] (🇷🇺), and the [[Flag of the United States|United States]] (🇺🇸). Encoding these flags but not other countries' flags was considered, by some, as prejudicial.<ref>{{cite web | title = L2/09-114 N3607: Towards an encoding of symbol characters used as emoji | date = 2009-04-06 | url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2009/09114-n3607-emoji.pdf | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref> One rejected solution was to encode the ten flags but call them "EMOJI COMPATIBILITY SYMBOL-n" and represent them visually in the Standard as "EC n" instead of showing the flags they represent.<ref>{{cite web | title = INCITS/L2/09-304: Comments accompanying the U.S. negative vote on PDAM 8 to ISO/IEC 10646:2003 (SC2 N4078) | date = 2009-08-15 | url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2009/09304-usnb-cmts-rev-pdam8.pdf | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref> Another rejected solution would have allocated 676 codepoints (26 x 26) for each possible two letter combination of A–Z. They would represent political entities based on [[ISO 3166]] such as "FR" for France or Internet ccTLDs ([[country code top-level domain|country code top-level domains]]) such as "EU" for the European Union.<ref>{{cite web | first = Karl | last = Pentzlin | title = L2/08-305: Some suggestions about the encoding of national flags as requested by the Emoji proposal | date = 2008-08-09 | url = https://www.unicode.org/L2/L2008/08305-nat-flags.pdf | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref>
The accepted solution was to add 26 characters for letters used for the representation of regional indicators, which used in pairs would represent the ten national flags and possible future extensions.<ref name=n3727/> Per the Unicode Standard {{em|"the main purpose of such [regional indicator symbol] pairs is to provide unambiguous roundtrip mappings to certain characters used in the emoji core sets"}}<ref>{{cite book | title = The Unicode Standard, Version 6.2, Chapter 15: Symbols | publisher = Unicode, Inc | date = September 2012 | pages = 534 | url = https://www.unicode.org/versions/Unicode6.2.0/ch15.pdf | isbn = 978-1-936213-07-8}}</ref> specifically the ten national flags:<ref>{{cite web | title = Emoji Sources | publisher = Unicode, Inc. | date = 2013-12-17 | url = https://www.unicode.org/Public/UNIDATA/EmojiSources.txt | format = plain text | accessdate = 2014-08-18}}</ref> 🇨🇳, 🇩🇪, 🇪🇸, 🇫🇷, 🇬🇧, 🇮🇹, 🇯🇵, 🇰🇷, 🇷🇺, and 🇺🇸.
== References == {{reflist}}
{{Unicode navigation}} [[Category:Unicode special code points]] [[Category:Country codes]] [[Category:Emoji]] [[Category:Representations of flags]]

revision.comment: v1.39 - Repaired 1 link to disambiguation page - [[WP:DPL|(You can help)]] - [[Overcharging]]
revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=August 2012}} {{Use South African English|date=August 2012}} '''''S v Rabie'''''<ref>1975 (4) SA 855 (A).</ref> is an important case in [[South African law]], heard in the Appellate Division on 12 September 1975, with judgment handed down on 23 September. The presiding officers were Holmes JA, Corbett JA and Kotzé AJA. The case is significant primarily in the area of sentencing, with its determination that the punishment should
* fit the criminal as well as the crime; * be fair to society; and * be blended with a measure of mercy according to the circumstances.
The court held that in every appeal against a sentence, whether imposed by a magistrate or a Judge, the Court hearing the appeal
# should be guided by the principle that punishment is "pre-eminently a matter for the discretion of the trial Court"; and # should be careful not to erode such discretion; hence the further principle that the sentence should only be altered if the discretion has not been "judicially and properly exercised."
The test under the second of these points is whether the sentence is vitiated by irregularity or misdirection or is disturbingly inappropriate.
== Facts == The appellant had been convicted on nineteen counts of fraud, which had been taken together for the purposes of sentence, the appellant having been sentenced to
* a fine of R5 000; and * imprisonment for three years, of which two years had been suspended on relevant conditions.
In addition he had been convicted and fined on three counts of [[overcharge|overcharging]].
In an appeal against the sentence on the nineteen counts of fraud, it was contended that they amounted substantially to the same offence of overcharging in contravention of the Rents Act,<ref>Act 43 of 1950.</ref><ref>s 10(1)(a).</ref> for which the appellant had merely been fined on the other three counts on which he had been convicted.
== Judgment == The Court, however, found that the fraud was intended to be and was a cover-up for the unlawful overcharging of rents, and held that there was no basis for appellate interference with the trial Judge's sentence. The Appellate Division did not have an overriding discretion to ameliorate the sentences of trial Courts. The discretion was pre-eminently theirs, alterable only on the grounds mentioned above. The appeal was accordingly dismissed.
== See also == * [[Crime in South Africa]] * [[Criminal procedure in South Africa]] * [[Law of South Africa]] * [[South African criminal law]] * [[Sentence (law)]]
== References == === Case law === * ''S v Rabie'' 1975 (4) SA 855 (A).
=== Legislation === * Rents Act 43 of 1950.
== Notes == {{Reflist}}
[[Category:Appellate Division (South Africa) cases]] [[Category:1975 in South African law]] [[Category:1975 in case law]]
{{SouthAfrica-case-law-stub}}

revision.comment: Typo/[[WP:AWB/GF|general]] fixes, replaced: archeaological → archaeological, in 2 September 2018 → on 2 September 2018, ofthe → of the, [[WP:AWB/T|typo(s) fixed]]: i.e, → i.e.,, a important → an important
revision.text:
{{Infobox artwork | title = Sha-Amun-en-su | wikidata = | image = B_1431.jpg | image_upright = | alt = | caption = | artist = | year = ''c''. 750 B.C. | completion_date = | catalogue = | medium = Stucco and polychromated wood | movement = | subject = Sarcophagus and mummy | height_metric =1.58 | width_metric = | length_metric = | diameter_metric = | height_imperial = | width_imperial = | length_imperial = | diameter_imperial = | dimensions = | dimensions_ref = | metric_unit = m | imperial_unit = in | weight = | designation = | condition = Destroyed | museum = [[National Museum of Brazil|National Museum]] | city = [[Rio de Janeiro]] | coordinates = | owner = | accession = 1876 | module = | website = }} '''Sha-Amun-en-su''' ({{lang-egy|the fertile fields of Amun}}) was an [[Ancient Egypt|Egyptian]] priestess and singer who lived in [[Thebes, Egypt|Thebes]] during the first half of the [[8th century BC|8th century B.C.]], responsible for ceremonial duties at the [[Karnak|Temple of Karnak]], dedicated to the god [[Amun]]. Sha-Amun-en-su was a ''Heset'', i.e., a member of the foremost group of singers with ritualistic functions active in the temple of Amun. After her death, which is estimated to have occurred around the age of 50, the singer was [[Mummy|mummified]] and placed in a [[sarcophagus]] made of [[stucco]] and [[polychrome]] wood. Since its sealing, more than 2700 years ago, Sha-Amun-en-su's sarcophagus had never been opened, throughout its history, conserving inside the singer's mummy, a feature that gave it extreme rarity.{{Cite web|url=http://revistapesquisa.fapesp.br/2014/01/13/o-ultimo-ato-da-favorita-imperador/|title=O último ato da favorita do imperador : Revista Pesquisa Fapesp|website=revistapesquisa.fapesp.br|language=pt-br|access-date=2018-09-15}} The sarcophagus and its mummy were given as presents to the Brazilian emperor [[Pedro II of Brazil|Dom Pedro II]] during his second travel to Egypt, in 1876, by the [[Khedive]] [[Isma'il Pasha|Ismail Pasha]]. They became featured items displayed in the [[Quinta da Boa Vista|Palace of São Cristóvão]], integrating Pedro II's private collection until the [[Proclamation of the Republic (Brazil)|Proclamation of the Republic]], in 1889, when they became part of the  Egyptian collection of the [[National Museum of Brazil|National Museum]] of [[Rio de Janeiro]]. However, a [[National Museum of Brazil fire|large-scale fire in the museum]] on 2 September 2018, destroyed the sarcophagus and the mummy, as well as almost all archaeological artifacts in permanent display.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.com/portuguese/brasil-45391771|title=O que havia no acervo do Museu Nacional e foi consumido pelo fogo|date=2018-09-02|work=BBC News Brasil|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en-GB}} == Biography == [[File:Sha-Amun-en-su_(hieróglifos).jpg|left|thumb|250x250px|Hieroglyphic inscription of Sha-Amun-en-su name and title on the sarcophagus]] Sha-Amun-en-su was born circa the year 800 B.C., during the [[Twenty-second Dynasty of Egypt]]. Her name and almost all known information about her life come from the [[Hieroglyph|hieroglyphic inscriptions]] in her sarcophagus It is known that she was a "singer of Amun's sanctuary", that means, a singer with priestly assignments in the service of the Temple of Karnak  in the ancient city of Thebes (currently [[Luxor]]), devoted to the god [[Amun]]. Thebes was one of the most important religious centers in Ancient Egypt, congregating a complex of temples and hundreds of workers, among them priests, scribes, singers, musicians, managers and employees, with Karnak as its main temple.{{Cite journal|last=Brancaglion|first=Antonio|title=Sha-Amun-em-su Uma Cantora do Egito Antigo|url=http://www.academia.edu/36231588/Sha-Amun-em-su_Uma_Cantora_do_Egito_Antigo|language=pt}}Bakos, 1994, pp. 92-93. There were several categories of priestly singers at Amun's shrine. Sha-Amun-en-su belonged to the main group, called ''Heset'', women who exercised ritualistic functions and sang hymns in honor of the god Amun at sacred ceremonies and festivals, either as soloists or accompanied by female choirs. The  ''Heset'' tradition lasted in Thebes between the 9th to 6th centuries  B.C. Besides  singing the religious hymnns, they were responsible in hepling the "God's Wife of Amun" during the temple rites. [[File:Esquife_da_dama_Sha-amun-en-su_04.jpg|right|thumb|200x200px| Sha-Amun-en-su's sarcophagus]] The ''Heset'' were not obliged to live permanently in the temple and many of them attended only for the execution of the ceremonies. Nevertheless, they obeyed to strict codes of conduct. Preferently, they had to stay [[Chastity|chaste]], but, even though not being virgins, they were considered extremely pure, to such extent as performing their gifts in such an important and symbolic edification as the temple of  Amun. Although they were not members of the Egyptian nobility, the singers were chosen among members of local elites and prepared for the function from an early age, being "adopted" by an older singer who served as their tutor and, in fact, as an "adoptive mother". There are no information about Sha-Amun-en-su's biilogical family or foster mother. It is likely that, like most Heset, she came from a wealthy family traditionally linked to priestly activities. It is known, however, that sge had an "adopted daughter," based on the inscriptions of another sarcophagus currently preserved in the [[Egyptian Museum]] in Cairo — the casket of a singer called Merset-Amun, whose hieroglyphs report that she was "''daughter of Sha-Amun-en-su, singer of the shrine of Amun".'' Sha-Amun-en-su lived until around 50 years old, according to researches led by the National Museum's Laboratory of Egyptology. The death causes could not be determined. == Mummy == After the singer's death, her body was mummified by Egyptian priests and placed into a sarcophagus. Sha-Amun-en-su's coffin cover has never been removed, preventing the mummy from being studied by the naked eye. Thus, all analyzes of the coffin's inner structure and mummy status depended on X-ray examinations, computerized tomography, and three-dimensional scans. The set consisting of the sarcophagus and its mummy possessed great historical and scientific value, especially in relation to the knowledge of the funerary practices and rituals of the Temple of Ámon, since mummies of Egyptian singers are rare and even rarer are mummies of singers deposited in sealed coffins. Some features of the Sha-Amun-en-su mummification process were also quite specific and accentuated its rarity. Although most of the mummification process has followed traditional procedures, such as evisceration of the body and its wrapping with linen bandages, research coordinated by archaeologist {{ill|Antonio Brancaglion Junior|pt}}, curator of the Egyptian collection of the National Museum, revealed that the mummy's throat was covered with resin-coated bandages. This particularity indicates a concern of the mummifying priests to protect a zone seen as "vital" for a singer with ritualistic functions that, according to the Egyptian beliefs, would continue using her gift in the afterlife.{{Cite web|url=https://www1.folha.uol.com.br/serafina/2015/11/1697689-essa-e-a-mistura-do-brasil-com-o-egito-mumia-passeia-por-shopping-na-barra.shtml|title=Essa é a mistura do Brasil com o Egito: múmia passeia por shopping na Barra - 25/10/2015 - Serafina - Folha de S.Paulo|website=www1.folha.uol.com.br|access-date=2018-09-15}} The Institute of Oriental Studies at the [[University of Chicago]] preserves in its collection another mummy, also in a sealed sarcophagus, called [[Meresamun]] ("Amun's beloved", in Egyptian language). Like Sha-Amun-en-su, she was also a singer of the Amun temple during the 22nd Dynasty and her mummy also boasts a kind of protection in her throat. Meresamun was about 30 years old at her death. Her mouth and throat are lined with a padded protection, apparently made with pressed earth and bandages. Based on these common characteristics between the two mummies, Brancaglion hypothesized that there were specific standards of mummification for the women in charge of chanting hymns and songs in the Temple of Karnak. Anatomical analysis of the Sha-Amun-en-su mummy failed to determine the cause of her death. It is known, anyway, that the singer was around 50 years old when she died. The mummy's body appeared to be in good condition, with no traumas or injuries. The examinations also allowed to observe a very rare dental curiosity: the mummy still kept almost all her teeth, missing only one. The Sha-Amun-en-su mummy also underwent a three-dimensional laser scan coordinated by Jorge Lopes, from the Tri-dimensional Experimentation Nucleus of the [[Pontifical Catholic University of Rio de Janeiro]]. That procedure allowed the generation of three-dimensional data files (called "orthogonal coordinates") that served as the basis for making a small-scale replica of the singer's skeleton. == Funerary artifacts == Computed tomography analysis, coordinated by radiologist Iugiro Kuroki, under the supervision of paleopathologist Sheila Mendonça of [[Oswaldo Cruz Foundation|Fiocruz]], identified several amulets with votive functions stored inside the coffin, including a heart-scarab, an artifact related to Egyptian belief in the resurrection of the dead. Sha-Amun-en-su's heart-scarab consisted of a green stone of oval shape, set in a gold plaque and attached to a golden cord, with the name of the singer written in hieroglyphs. These artifacts were often placed on the heart of the mummy and had the function of "replacing" it in cases in which the organ was extracted during the evisceration process. In this way the priests sought to preserve the "integrity" of the deceased in the afterlife, as well as the functions, states, characteristics, and other attributes that ancient Egyptians attached to the heart, such as intelligence and feelings. == Sarcophagus == [[File:Caixão_de_Sha-Amun-En-Su.jpg|right|thumb|240x240px|Profile face detail on the sarcophagus of Sha-Amun-in-su.]] The Sha-Amun-en-su sarcophagus was composed of box and lid, both carved in polychrome stuccoed wood.It was 1,58 meters high and was made around 750 BC. Throughout its nearly three millennia of history, since it had been sealed with the mummified body of the singer and her votive amulets, the sarcophagus had never been opened.It was a highly representative example of Egyptian funerary art from the 8th and 9th centuries BC, characterized by the profusion of references to [[Heliopolis (ancient Egypt)|Heliopolitan]] theology. The top of the sarcophagus cover was decorated with a female face, which sought to represent the natural color of the skin, topped with a blue headdress, decorated with yellow vulture wings and yellow and red ribbons. Shades of dark green, red and yellow stood out against a white background. At the breast height, there was the figure of the goddess [[Nut (goddess)|Nut]] and a representation of a ram-headed bird with wings outstretched over the lid, symbolizing protection. The bird's claws and tail were flanked by two [[uraeus]] serpents, one with the crown of [[Upper Egypt]] and one with the crown of [[Lower Egypt]] The four [[Sons of Horus]] were represented in two pairs, one pair in front of each snake.On the right side were [[Imset]] with a human head and [[Hapy]] with a baboon's head, and on the left side [[Duamutef]] with a jackal's head and [[Qebehsenuf]] with a hawk's head. In the region of the legs were represented the amulets of the god [[Osiris]], flanked by divinities. The two halves of the sarcophagus were separated by the sign [[Ankh]], the symbol of life, which was repeated in two other ribbons. Finally, there was a representation of the singer's [[Ba (soul)|Ba]] - Ba was understood at the same time as a spiritual component of human beings, gods and animals, as a metaphysical principle related to the individuality of being and as a dynamic element that separates from the body after death, approaching, in this sense, the Western concept of soul. At the back and outside of the sarcophagus was a representation of the great [[Djed]] pillar, a sign of stability associated with Osiris, the Egyptian god of the afterlife, who ruled the underworld and the dead. In different parts of the coffin, there were bands with hieroglyphic inscriptions, analyzed and studied by different Egyptologists, such as [[Kenneth Kitchen]] and Alberto Childe. Kitchen was the first to identify the mummy, deciphering two bands of distinct hieroglyphs that associated her name to her occupation. The first band bore the inscription'' "An offering that the king makes [to] Osiris, Chief of the West, great God, Lord of Abydos - made for [?] The Singer of the Shrine [of Ammon], Sha-Amun-en-su "''. In the second line of hieroglyphs was read: "''An offering that the king makes [to] Ptah-Sokar-Osiris, Lord of the [shrine] Shetayet - made for [?] The Singer of the Shrine of Ammon, Sha-Amun-en-su"''. == History == [[File:D._Pedro_II_e_sua_comitiva_visitando_as_pirâmides_em_1876.jpg|left|thumb|200x200px|Emperor Pedro II and his entourage visiting the Egyptian pyramids, in 1876.]] There is scarce information on the sarcophagus of Sha-Amun-en-su in the pre-nineteenth century period. There is no record of the date or exact archaeological site where the coffin was found (although it is known to come from the vast western Thebes complex), nor is there any information on the process of integrating the coffin into the [[Egyptian Khedivate]] collections. In 1876, during the second visit of Emperor Dom Pedro II to Egypt, the sarcophagus was offered as a gift to the Brazilian monarch by Ismail Pasha. In return, Pedro II offered a book to the Khedive. An amateur Egyptologist and enthusiast of Egyptian culture, Pedro II had a special affection for the sarcophagus, which soon became one of the most relevant pieces of his private collection. The emperor kept him standing in his study in the [[Quinta da Boa Vista|Palace of São Cristóvão]]. During its passage through the collection of Pedro II, the sarcophagus was damaged in the event of a storm. Knocked down by the wind, the sarcophagus fell, crashing into one of the emperor's office windows and having its left side fragmented. It was later restored, but the intervention would remain visible ever since. Other restorations would be carried out in the following decades aiming at eliminating, above all, the threats of termites and wasps, attracted by the oldness of the wood. The sarcophagus remained in the Palace of São Cristóvão after the Proclamation of the Republic in 1889, and was later integrated into the collection of Egyptian archeology of the National Museum of Rio de Janeiro. Since its integration into the museum collection, the sarcophagus has always been one of the most outstanding pieces of the collection, having served as the basis for a large number of scientific researches, theses and monographs, developed by researchers from the Federal University of Rio de Janeiro and others Brazilian scientific institutions and academics from different parts of the world. In 2015, commenting on the importance and uniqueness of the sarcophagus and the mummy of Sha-Amun-en-su, the curator of the Egyptian National Museum's collection, Antonio Brancaglion Junior, stated: {{cquote|If you have a mummy, you have a mummy, if you have not, you won't get one anymore. If we lose it, we will never get anything else remotely similar. We have to keep it to the end.}} On September 2, 2018, a major fire destroyed the building of the National Museum and much of the collection on display, including the sarcophagus of Sha-Amun-en-su, with its mummy and all the votive artifacts conserved within it. In the fire, the other mummies and sarcophagi of the collection, along with most of the archaeological collection, were also lost. The fire caused great commotion in the academic, scientific and cultural circles of Brazil and the world. == See also == * [[Collection of funerary steles in the National Museum of Brazil]] * [[Collection of mummies in the National Museum of Brazil]] * [[Egyptology]] * [[National Museum of Brazil fire]] == References == {{Reflist}} == Bibliography ==
* {{cite book | last = Bakos | first = Margaret | title = Egiptomania : o egito no Brasil | publisher = Paris Ed | location = São Paulo | year = 2004 | isbn = 8572442618|ref=harv }} * {{cite book|last=Marchiori Bakos|first=Margaret|title=Fatos e mitos do antigo Egito|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fcqVDgAAQBAJ|date=3 April 2017|publisher=EDIPUCRS|isbn=978-85-397-0458-3|ref=harv}} * Brancaglion Junior, Antonio. "Revelando o Passado: estudos da coleção egípcia do Museu Nacional". In: Lessa, Fábio de Souza & Bustamente, Regina (2007). ''Memoria & festa'' (Rio de Janeiro: Mauad Editora), pp. 75–80. {{ISBN|8574781789}}.
== External links == * [http://www.museunacional.ufrj.br/ Página oficial do Museu Nacional] * [http://revistapesquisa.fapesp.br/2014/01/13/o-ultimo-ato-da-favorita-imperador/ "O último ato da favorita do imperador" - Artigo sobre Sha-Amun-en-su na Revista Pesquisa Fapesp] [[Category:People of the Twenty-second Dynasty of Egypt]] [[Category:Art of ancient Egypt]] [[Category:Female singers]] [[Category:Egyptian singers]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian women]] [[Category:Ancient Egyptian mummies]] [[Category:Sarcophagi]] [[Category:National Museum of Brazil]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2017}} {{Use British English|date=November 2017}} '''''Stour''''' is an all-wooden motor [[narrow boat]] powered by a [[Bolinder-Munktell|Bolinder]] 15 h. p. diesel engine. It was built as a tar tanker in 1937 by [[Fellows Morton and Clayton]] at their [[Uxbridge]] dockyard for fuel oil carriers Thomas Clayton Ltd of Oldbury.
The hull has oak planked sides, elm bottoms and pine deck with a fully fitted traditional boatman’s cabin. She was one of a large fleet of all wooden boats used by that Company for liquid cargo carrying, the main hold area being fully decked over.
When new it would have carried refined fuels such as gas oil for powering machinery but as it got older it was used for carrying heavier lubricating oil from the fuel distribution plants on the [[Manchester Ship Canal]].
It is now owned by the [[Black Country Living Museum]], in [[Dudley]], where it is based and can be seen dockside in the Lord Ward’s Canal Arm at the museum.
Stour is on the [[National Historic Ships|'' National Historic Ships]] register.
==External links== * [http://www.nationalhistoricships.org.uk/register/2385/stour/ National Historic Ships website ] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20130508135121/http://www.bclm.co.uk/locations/the-boat-dock--boat-collection/46.htm Black Country Living Museum website ] {{National Historic Ships}}
[[Category:Black Country Living Museum]] [[Category:Canal boats of the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Ships and vessels on the National Register of Historic Vessels]]

revision.text:
{{italic title}} {{Infobox book | name = The Bacon Cookbook | title_orig = | translator = | image = The Bacon Cookbook.jpg | caption = Picture of bacon frying in a pan | author = James Villas | illustrator = Andrea Grablewski | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | subject = [[Bacon]] | publisher = [[Wiley (publisher)|Wiley]] | pub_date = 2007 | english_pub_date = | media_type = Hardback | pages = 288 | isbn = 0-470-04282-6 | oclc = 84838803 | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = The Glory of Southern Cooking | followed_by = Pig: King of the Southern Table }} '''''The Bacon Cookbook: More than 150 Recipes from Around the World for Everyone's Favorite Food''''' is a [[cookbook]] on [[bacon]] by James Villas. It was published by [[Wiley (publisher)|Wiley]] in 2007. Villas is a former food editor for ''[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]'' magazine, and ''The Bacon Cookbook'' is his 15th book on food. He notes on the book's jacket that he was "beguiled by bacon since he was a boy."<ref name="publishers" /> He describes the appeal of bacon in the book's preface, and in the introduction recounts the history of the product, as well as its variations from different locations internationally. Chapters are structured by type of recipe and food course, and in total the book includes 168 recipes.
The book received generally positive reception in book reviews and media sources, receiving praise in ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' and ''[[Library Journal]]''. In 2009 the [[National Pork Board]] highlighted recipes from the book for [[International Bacon Day]]. Chef [[Bobby Flay]] highlighted one recipe from ''The Bacon Cookbook'', for "Bacon-Wrapped Figs Stuffed With Almonds In Port", as one of his favorites.<ref name="bobbyflay" /> ''[[AM New York]]'', ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'', and the ''[[Star Tribune]]'', recommended the book in articles on suggested gift-giving ideas. ''[[The Independent]]'' highlighted the book as number 11 on a list of "The 50 Best Cookbooks".
==Content summary== In the preface to the book, Villas states that vegetarians and those that do not eat pork for religious reasons are "haunted instinctively by the sensuous, irresistible enticement".<ref name="publishers" /> He asserts, "There's no one who doesn't love bacon. It's the greatest food God has ever created."<ref name="vann" /> Villas asks, "Who, under any circumstances, is not rendered almost helpless by the tantalizing sound of bacon sizzling slowly in a skillet, by the taunting backwoods aroma that permeates the air ...?"<ref name="sutton" /> He notes that "the greatest and most beloved food on earth" is one of the worlds oldest forms of cooked meat.<ref>{{cite news |last =Miliard |first =Mike |title =Hog wild! |work =Charlottesville News and Arts |publisher =Portico Publications |date =March 11, 2008 |url =http://www.c-ville.com/index.php?cat=121304062461064&ShowArticle_ID=11431003083173348 |accessdate =2009-12-12 }}</ref> The author comments on the surge in interest in bacon products in the years prior to the book's publication, "Just the 40 percent increase in bacon consumption in the United States over the past five years might have justified my writing this book."<ref>{{cite news |last =Lapan |first =Tovin |title =Wrapped Up in Bacon |work =The Paramus Post|location=Paramus, New Jersey |publisher =paramuspost.com |date =June 27, 2009 |url =http://www.paramuspost.com/article.php/20090626202111765 |accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> The book includes photographs by Andrea Grablewski.<ref name="sutton" />
The introduction contains a guide to "the international world of bacon",<ref name="sutton" /> and Villas compares dishes Salt Pork and Pancetta; and Paprikaspeck and Bauchspeck.<ref name="publishers" /> The introduction also includes a list of places to receive mail-order products.<ref name="publishers" /> The book goes over the history of curing bacon, discussing the various international traditions.<ref name="culbertson" /> Smokehouses listed as resources in the book include Benton's in [[Tennessee]], Newsom's in [[Kentucky]], Edwards & Sons in [[Virginia]], Nueske in [[Wisconsin]], and Lazy H Smokehouse in [[Kirbyville, Texas]].<ref name="culbertson" /> Villas instructs the reader in techniques of smoking bacon, how to buy and store it, and how to utilize bacon fat for cooking purposes.<ref name="vann" />
Villas explains the derivation of the phrase "bring home the bacon", writing, "An Old English tradition whereby a flitch, or side, of bacon was offered as a prize to any man who could swear before the church that for a year and a day he had neither quarreled with his wife nor wished himself single."<ref name="winston" /> He recounts how the Chinese discovered methods of preserving [[pork belly|pork bellies]] around 1500 B.C.<ref name="winston" /> By the first century A.D., [[Ancient Rome|Romans]] had established a practice of breeding hogs for the production of bacon.<ref name="winston" /> During the [[Middle Ages]], bacon and beans was considered a [[staple food]] for the poor.<ref name="winston" /> According to Villas, bacon was eaten aboard the ''[[Mayflower]]'', and was a staple food product in the [[European colonization of the Americas|early American colonies]].<ref>{{cite news |last =The Douglas Daily Dispatch staff |title =Bacon adds sizzle to mealtime |work =The Douglas Daily Dispatch|location=Douglas, Arizona |publisher =douglasdispatch.com |date =October 16, 2007 |url =http://www.douglasdispatch.com/articles/2007/10/17/news/food/food1.txt|accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> Villas describes how [[Oscar F. Mayer]] began to package sliced bacon for his customers during the 1920s.<ref name="winston" /> The author describes contemporary practices of utilizing old-fashioned style curing and smoking methods by food manufacturers in the United States.<ref name="winston" />
Chapters are structured according to each type of recipe, including main course, soup, and breads.<ref name="vann" /> 168 recipes from the United States and globally are included in the book.<ref name="vann" /> The author notes that bacon is not as bad nutritionally as had previously been thought.<ref name="culbertson" /> He compares the nutritional characteristics of two slices of cooked bacon to one pork hot dog, noting that the bacon contains approximately "73 calories, 202 milligrams of sodium, 6 grams of fat and 11 milligrams of cholesterol", while the hot dog has "182 calories, 638 milligrams of sodium, 17 grams of fat and 29 milligrams of cholesterol".<ref name="culbertson" /> "If health concerns sometimes make you feel guilty about loving bacon ... relax ...yes, it’s high in sodium and fat, but if eaten in moderation or used as a flavoring agent ... it is a guilt free indulgence," writes Villas.<ref name="grant">{{cite news |last =Grant |first =Dorothy |title =One of the best food aromas in the world is bacon |work =TCPalm |publisher =Scripps Interactive Newspapers Group |date =April 7, 2008 |url =http://www.tcpalm.com/news/2008/apr/07/dorothy-grant-one-best-food-aromas-world-bacon/ |accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> Breakfast dishes include French Cheese and Bacon souffle, and Bacon Scrapple.<ref name="publishers" /> A recipe for [[BLT sandwich]] is included in the section on sandwiches, but the majority of Villas's other sandwich recipes are more extreme, and include ingredients such as Jamaican smoked fish.<ref name="publishers" /> Dishes that contain vegetables include Lima Bean and Bacon Casserole; and Spanish Chicken, Bacon, Meatball and Chickpea Stew.<ref name="publishers" /> For dessert, Villas includes six recipes such as bacon-wrapped figs, and Bacon and Peanut Butter Chocolate Truffles, and Portuguese Egg and Bacon Pudding.<ref name="publishers" /><ref name="sutton" />
==Background== James Villas is a former food editor for ''[[Town & Country (magazine)|Town & Country]]'' magazine.<ref name="publishers" /> The back flap of the book's jacket notes that Villas was "beguiled by bacon since he was a boy."<ref name="publishers" /> Prior to ''The Bacon Cookbook'', Villas had written other cookbooks including ''The Glory of Southern Cooking'', ''My Mother's Southern Kitchen'', and ''Biscuit Bliss''.<ref name="sutton" /><ref name="culbertson" /> ''The Bacon Cookbook'' is his 15th book on food.<ref name="winston">{{cite news |last =Winston-Salem Journal staff |title =A book that needs little help selling the sizzle |work =[[Winston-Salem Journal]]|location=[[Winston-Salem, North Carolina]] |page =D1 |date =December 12, 2007 }}</ref> In the lead-up to the 2009 [[International Bacon Day]], Villas commented to ''Pork Magazine'', "People are starting to realize that bacon is no longer just a breakfast staple. Bacon is, without a doubt, one of the most versatile and flavorful options in the grocery aisle. Most importantly, a little bacon goes a long way. A sprinkle can enhance not only the flavor, but also the aroma and appeal of nearly any dish. We’re seeing chefs and home cooks add bacon to dishes you wouldn’t expect, like popcorn or cookies, and take traditional tastes to another dimension."<ref name="porkmag09">{{cite news |last =Pork news staff |title =Celebrate International Bacon Day Sept. 5 |work =Pork Magazine |publisher =Vance Publishing Corp.| date =August 31, 2009}}</ref> Villas explained to ''[[Salon.com|Salon]]'', "Bacon has the perfect balance of sweet, salty, smoky flavor, and the perfect balance of meaty and crispy texture."<ref>{{cite news |last =Hepola |first =Sarah |title =Bacon mania |work =[[Salon.com|Salon]] |date =July 7, 2008 |url =http://www.salon.com/mwt/feature/2008/07/07/bacon_mania/ |accessdate = 2009-12-12}}</ref> Villas commented to ''[[CBS News]]'' that his book was part of a growing interest in bacon products, "We have a lot more conscientious producers today, you know, really turning out fresh great product like we've got here in this store. I mean quality bacon. And America really should be out there searching for this stuff. And it'll change your life. It will really change your life."<ref name="bobbyflay" />
==Reception== {{quote box |width=25em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7 |align=right |halig=left|salign=right|quote="Bacon is a standard choice for many a simple supper, but there is nothing standard about Villas's book. The irresistible smell of bacon oozes from the pages, as Villas shows the versatility of bacon..."|source= —Rhiannon Batten, ''[[The Independent]]''<ref name=Independent/>}}
A review in ''[[Publishers Weekly]]'' called the book an "exuberant parade of pork fat", and commented, "there's plenty good to be had in these pages".<ref name="publishers">{{cite journal |last =Publishers Weekly staff |title =The Bacon Cookbook |journal =[[Publishers Weekly]] |volume =254 |issue =35 |page =55 |date =September 3, 2007 }}</ref> Writing for ''[[Library Journal]]'', Judith Sutton concluded, "There are, in fact, several other cookbooks devoted to bacon, including Sara Perry's ''Everything Tastes Better with Bacon'', but with its irresistible recipes and wealth of information and lore, Villas's new title is recommended for most collections."<ref name="sutton">{{cite journal |last =Sutton |first =Judith |title =The Bacon Cookbook: More Than 125 Recipes from Around the World for Everyone's Favorite Food |journal =[[Library Journal]] |volume =132 |issue =17 |page =87 |location=New York |date =October 15, 2007 }}</ref> Amy Culbertson of the ''[[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]'' also compared the Villas's work to another book on bacon, writing, "His is a more definitive cookbook than last year's "Seduced by Bacon" by Joanna Pruess".<ref name="culbertson">{{cite news |last =Culbertson |first =Amy ([[Fort Worth Star-Telegram]]) |title =When you cook with bacon, it's all good |work =[[The Commercial Appeal]]|location=Memphis, Tennessee | date =October 10, 2007 |url =http://www.commercialappeal.com/news/2007/oct/10/when-you-cook-with-bacon-its-all-good/|accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> The book was highlighted in the "Holiday Cookbook Roundup: Gift Guide" column of ''[[The Austin Chronicle]]'', where writer Mick Vann concluded, "This is one of the few cookbooks you'll find where every single recipe makes you want to head straight for the stove, whether it's a bacon, goat cheese, and sweet-onion pie; Russian borscht; beef-stuffed plantains; or braised Japanese pork belly. For those fellow bacon lovers in our midst, Villas' The Bacon Cookbook is required reading."<ref name="vann">{{cite news |last =Vann |first =Mick |title =Holiday Cookbook Roundup: Gift Guide |work =[[The Austin Chronicle]] |publisher =Austin Chronicle Corp.|date =December 14, 2007 |url =http://www.austinchronicle.com/gyrobase/Issue/story?oid=oid%3A571853|accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> In honor of [[International Bacon Day]] in 2009, the [[National Pork Board]] offered recipes from ''The Bacon Cookbook''.<ref name="porkmag09" /> Bonnie Stern of ''[[Financial Post]]'' recommended the book, and commented, "Few of us can resist the allure of sizzling, smokey, crispy bacon. Though not usually high on the list of foods that are considered good for you, if you don't eat it often, you can have your bacon and eat it, too. If you want to know all about bacon, have a look at The Bacon Cookbook by James Villas".<ref>{{cite news |last =Stern |first =Bonnie |title =A trio of favourite bacon recipes |work =[[Financial Post]] |publisher =National Post Inc. |date =January 26, 2008 |url =http://www.financialpost.com/scripts/story.html?id=5c30c611-bec0-49a9-98cc-0112715c8f28 |accessdate = 2009-12-12}}</ref>
Chef [[Bobby Flay]] highlighted the recipe from ''The Bacon Cookbook'' for "Bacon-Wrapped Figs Stuffed With Almonds In Port" as one of his favorites.<ref name="bobbyflay">{{cite news |last =Flay |first =Bobby|authorlink=Bobby Flay |title =Bobby Flay: Bacon's Back In A Big Way |work =[[CBS News]] |publisher =[[CBS]] |date =September 16, 2007 |url =http://www.cbsnews.com/stories/2007/09/16/sunday/main3264785.shtml |accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> Jonathan Cheung, co-owner of the cookbook store Bon Appétit in [[Montreal, Quebec]], Canada, recommended the book to his customers when they asked for books on cooking with pork products.<ref>{{cite news |last =Sokoloff |first =Heather |title =The five-minute Ramsay: recipes for 'busy' foodies |work =[[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher =CTVglobemedia Publishing Inc. |date =March 19, 2008 |url =https://www.theglobeandmail.com/life/article673628.ece |accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> ''[[AM New York]]'' highlighted the book among its recommendations of "Best cookbooks to give as gifts", noting that the author, "presents a mouthwatering array of recipes to nudge the pork lover."<ref>{{cite news |last =Perney |first =Linda |title =Best cookbooks to give as gifts |work =[[AM New York]] |publisher =exploreli.com |date =November 27, 2007 |url =http://www.exploreli.com/restaurants/best-cookbooks-to-give-as-gifts-1.877340 |accessdate = 2009-12-12}}</ref> Writing for ''[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Advocate]]'', Cheramie Sonnier commented, "James Villas comes through once again with a cookbook that is sure to please cooks who love both classic comfort foods and exotic new dishes."<ref>{{cite news |last =Sonnier |first =Cheramie |title =Tantalizing bacon dishes get spotlight in Villas' cookbook |work =[[The Advocate (Louisiana)|The Advocate]]|location=Baton Rouge, Louisiana |page =G1 |date =November 8, 2007 }}</ref> The ''[[San Jose Mercury News]]'' noted that Villas "turns his meticulous eye to the cured pork product" in the book, which includes "recipes featuring bacon in every imaginable way".<ref>{{cite news |last =San Jose Mercury News staff |title =Bacon perks up many a dish |work =[[San Jose Mercury News]] |page =2E; Section: Food |date =March 12, 2008 }}</ref> The ''[[Winston-Salem Journal]]'' observed, "His history of bacon, short and to the point, should be required reading for bacon lovers."<ref name="winston" /> ''[[The Baltimore Sun]]'' highlighted the book in an article "Gifts to savor", commenting that "James Villas covers everything about this trendy ingredient".<ref>{{cite news |last =Shatzkin|first = Kate |author2=Joannah Hill |title =Gifts to savor|work =[[The Baltimore Sun]]|location =[[Baltimore, Maryland]]|page =F1; Section: Taste|date =December 5, 2007 }}</ref> Marialisa Calta of ''The Douglas Daily Dispatch'' wrote, "in the unusual-but-oddly-compelling-single-subject-cookbook category, props go to “The Bacon Cookbook” by James Villas".<ref>{{cite news |last =Calta |first =Marialisa |title =Have a happy, tasty holiday |work =The Douglas Daily Dispatch|location=Douglas, Arizona |publisher =douglasdispatch.com |date =December 11, 2007 |url =http://www.douglasdispatch.com/articles/2007/12/11/news/food/doc475ef4dd484f6170629269.txt |accessdate = 2009-12-12 }}</ref> Writing for the ''[[Star Tribune]]'', Lee Svitak Dean recommended the book as a holiday gift for cooks, commenting, "It's all here, from guacamole and bacon canapés to New England apple and bacon griddlecakes and German fennel and bacon soup."<ref>{{cite news |last =Dean |first =Lee Svitak |title =Books for cooks |work =[[Star Tribune]]|location=Minneapolis, Minnesota |date =December 10, 2007|url =http://www.startribune.com/lifestyle/taste/12149671.html |accessdate =2009-12-12 }}</ref> "No publishing season is complete without a bacon book," wrote Kristen Browning-Blas of ''[[The Denver Post]]'', who noted that Joanna Pruess's ''[[Seduced by Bacon]]'' was released the previous year.<ref>{{cite news |last =Browning-Blas |first = Kristen |title =Cooking – Tome on a range: Big books are hot |work =[[The Denver Post]] |page =F15; Section: Features |date =December 2, 2007 }}</ref> The ''[[New York Daily News]]'' noted that the book "includes an introductory primer on the many wondrous bacon varieties along with easy-to-follow instruction for more than 150 international dishes, from guacamole with bacon to bacon-duck stew."<ref>{{cite news |last =New York Daily News staff |title =Food news bites |work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|location=New York |date =October 17, 2007}}</ref> ''[[The Independent]]'' highlighted the book as number 11 on a list of "The 50 Best Cookbooks", commenting, "Bacon is a standard choice for many a simple supper, but there is nothing standard about Villas's book. The irresistible smell of bacon oozes from the pages, as Villas shows the versatility of bacon, even bacon desserts – for example, bacon and peanut butter chocolate truffles. Vegetarians beware; these dishes could prove too tempting."<ref name=Independent>{{cite news |last =Batten |first =Rhiannon |title =The 50 Best Cookbooks |work =[[The Independent]]|date =September 13, 2008 |url =https://www.independent.co.uk/life-style/food-and-drink/features/the-50-best-cookbooks-928214.html?action=Popup&ino=11 |accessdate = 2009-12-12}}</ref>
